text:
Broadway, west side, south across Warren Street, showing the building frontage that faces City Hall Park (left). Warren Street is to the right center. Beyond are Park Place and Barclay Streets. The spire of St. Pauls Chapel o'ertowers the buildings lying between the last two thoroughfares.

About 1870

American Studio, photo
87 Nassau Street, N.Y.C.

Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RIGHTS UNKNOWN

Broadway, at the S. W. corner of Warren Street, as photographed from the enclosed City Hall Park. Note the posters on one of the stone gate supports. They read "Murder-Rom(an)-Catholics" and "California". The riot of 1871 caused by the attack of the Irish Catholics on the parading Orangemen, and the Gold Rush to California leads the writer to the concluded date of 1871 instead of the given 1854.

1871

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broadway, north from and including Warren Street (left) showing the horse drawn traffic upon this cobble stoned thoroughfare. On the right appears City Hall Park and the A.T. Stewart Building. The building on the extreme left is the present Rogers, Peet and Co. Building which at the time this photo was taken was occupied by Devlin and Co., Clothiers.

About 1888.

Brown Brothers.

title: Broadway, East Side. City Hall Park.

text:
#258 Broadway, at the South West corner of Warren Street.
March 30th, 1912.
Wurts Bros. Photographers,

#261 Broadway at the North West corner of Warren Street.

April 24th, 1912.

title: Broadway - Warren Street, east side - looking north

text:
(1)
Warren Street, Broeadway to Church Street. (Before Reconstruction).
September 11, 1918.

(2)
Same. (After Reconstruction).
September 11, 1918.

(1)
Warren Street, Broeadway to Church Street. (Before Reconstruction).
September 11, 1918.

(2)
Same. (After Reconstruction).
September 11, 1918.

Broadway, north from Warren (left) Street. On the right across a corner of City Hall Park is the 7-story Sun Building (formerly Stewarts).

1925.

(1)
Broadway, west side, between Warren (left) and Chambers (right) Streets, as seen from the Municipal Building, and across the roof of Court House. The buildings flying flags, are a single unit, and are known as 270 Broadway. They occupy the former site of the Chemical National Bank.

June 3, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same as viewed westward on Chambers Street, showing the National Shoe and Leather Bank (No. 271) and the Chemical National Bank (No. 270) that were demolished in 1928 for the site of the structure shown in No. 1, at the S.W. corner of Broadway and Chambers Street.

October 30, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Broadway, west side, between Warren (left) and Chambers (right) Streets, as seen from the Municipal Building, and across the roof of Court House. The buildings flying flags, are a single unit, and are known as 270 Broadway. They occupy the former site of the Chemical National Bank.

June 3, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same as viewed westward on Chambers Street, showing the National Shoe and Leather Bank (No. 271) and the Chemical National Bank (No. 270) that were demolished in 1928 for the site of the structure shown in No. 1, at the S.W. corner of Broadway and Chambers Street.

October 30, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, west side, south from Warren Street, to and including Park Place, as viewed across City Hall Park from the Municipal Building. Shown on the extreme left, is a portion of the Woolworth Building (south west corner of Park Place). The New York Telephone Building appears silhouetted against the hudson River.

June 3, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway (center, building fronts) west side, from Warren (left) to Chambers (right) Streets, showing at the S.W. corner of the latter point the recently constructed (about 1930) office building, No. 270 Broadway. The photographer is viewing westward to the North (Hudson) River from a vantage point atop the Municipal Building. To the left margin is the New York Telephone Building on West Street.

June 23, 1933

P.L. Sperr

Broadway, west side, south from Warren Street. Prominently shown, is the Woolworth Building, towering over the old United States Post Office, at the southern end of City Hall Park.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

(1) Broadway, south from Warren Street, and showing on the east side, a portion of City Hall Park, with the United States Post Office on its southern boundary (Mail Street). Appearing across the skyline, are the 60 Wall Street Tower, the twin spires of the Park Row Building and the triangular St. Paul Building. November 6, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A similar view prior to the demolition of the Postoffice Building. In May 1939 this feature will have completely disappeared.

July 4, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Broadway, south from Warren Street, and showing on the east side, a portion of City Hall Park, with the United States Post Office on its southern boundary (Mail Street). Appearing across the skyline, are the 60 Wall Street Tower, the twin spires of the Park Row Building and the triangular St. Paul Building. November 6, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A similar view prior to the demolition of the Postoffice Building. In May 1939 this feature will have completely disappeared.

July 4, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, west side, north from Warren Street, as viewed from City Hall Park, (east side of Broadway, between Mail and Chambers Streets). The 12-story structure partially shown on the left, is the City Hall Building, Nos. 260-261 Broadway, and is at the N.W. corner of Warren Street. A portion of the Sun Building appears on the right.

August 15, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
